content: The Act titled "Twenty-First Century Manufacturing Skills and Jobs Act of 2014" allows for federal matching payments for state new manufacturing jobs training tax credits. The "Twenty-First Century Manufacturing Skills and Jobs Act of 2014" authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to make quarterly payments to eligible community colleges based on new manufacturing job withholding matches for trainees. The withholding match is determined by amounts remitted by participating manufacturing employers. The new manufacturing job withholding match for eligible trainees is based on amounts remitted by participating employers. An eligible community college is defined as a public institution where the majority of degrees awarded are 2-year associate's degrees acceptable for full credit towards a baccalaureate degree. The text chunk discusses higher education institutions that offer 2-year associate's degrees acceptable for full credit towards a baccalaureate degree, located in states with a new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program, and participating in the program through a specific contract. The State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program is a program established by a State government that allows eligible community colleges and manufacturing employers to sign a contract for eligible trainees, resulting in State income tax credits for the employer. The State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program allows eligible community colleges and manufacturing employers to sign a contract for eligible trainees. State income taxes withheld by the employer for the trainee's qualified training costs will be remitted to the community college. The State's new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program allows eligible community colleges and manufacturing employers to sign a contract for eligible trainees. State income taxes withheld by the employer for the trainee's qualified training costs will be remitted to the community college, where it will be treated as payment for education provided. The amounts remitted will be treated as if they had been paid to the State for income taxes owed by the trainee. The qualified contract between an eligible community college and a manufacturing employer must meet all applicable requirements. The contract between an eligible community college and a manufacturing employer in a specific state must meet all state program requirements and provide qualified training directly to designated individuals. The eligible community college will provide qualified training to individuals designated by the employer, who will then be hired for full-time employment by the employer within the State. The individuals will receive a wage that is not less than a specified amount. The employer will pay individuals hired from the eligible community college a wage that is at least 175 percent of the Federal minimum wage or the amount specified under the State program. The employer will also remit State income taxes withheld on behalf of the employees. The employer will remit State income taxes withheld on behalf of individuals to the community college for training costs specified in the contract. The employer will remit State income taxes withheld on behalf of individuals to the community college for training costs specified in the contract. Qualified training, as defined in this section, includes education or training that provides individuals with necessary skills for their job. The contract must specify the entire cost of training, including equipment and materials, and the terms must be reasonable by market standards. The term "qualified training" refers to education or training that equips individuals with the necessary skills for their job, including skills needed to obtain required licenses or certifications under government regulations. The individual must have a certificate or credential required by government regulations or aligned with industry standards for the new job. The State program for new manufacturing jobs training tax credit requires employers to hire eligible trainees for new jobs that meet industry standards. To qualify for the new manufacturing jobs training tax credit, employers must hire eligible trainees for new jobs that are not recalled, replacement, or existing within the past year. To qualify for the new manufacturing jobs training tax credit, employers must hire eligible trainees for new jobs that result in a net increase in employment for the employer within the 1-year period preceding the date of hire. Only U.S. employees are taken into account for this credit. The new manufacturing jobs training tax credit requires employers to hire eligible trainees for new jobs that lead to a net increase in employment. Only U.S. employees are considered for this credit. The new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program allows employers to hire eligible trainees for new jobs leading to a net increase in employment. Employers working with local workforce investment boards can participate in the program. The new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program allows employers to hire eligible trainees for new jobs with the help of local workforce investment boards. Eligible trainees must have received qualified training through an eligible community college. The term "eligible trainee" refers to an individual who received qualified training from an eligible community college under a state new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program and is employed full-time by the employer in the same state as the college. (f) Eligible Manufacturing Employer.--For purposes of this section, payment is made by the employer at a job site in the same State as the eligible community college, at a wage meeting requirements, in a new job, and requiring qualified training. For eligibility as an "eligible manufacturing employer," the business must employ individuals in manufacturing, have facilities in the US, and be classified in sectors 31, 32, or 33 of the NAICS. An eligible manufacturing employer must have manufacturing facilities in the US and be classified in sectors 31, 32, or 33 of the NAICS. Appropriations are made from the Treasury for this purpose. State income tax withholdings remitted to a community college are not considered payments for training or education. The remission of State income tax withholdings by an eligible manufacturing employer to a community college is not considered as payments for training or education. Instead, it is treated as if the amount had been remitted to the State in payment of income taxes owed by the employee. The remission of State income tax withholdings by an eligible manufacturing employer to a community college is not considered as payments for training or education. Instead, it is treated as if the amount had been remitted to the State in payment of income taxes owed by the employee. In the case of an eligible trainee, withheld State income tax remitted to an eligible community college or payments made under subsection (a) are not treated as income for the trainee under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The remission of State income tax withholdings by an eligible manufacturing employer to a community college is treated as income of the eligible trainee for tax purposes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amounts described in paragraph (1) are considered as amounts paid for State income taxes by the eligible trainee for deduction purposes.
